questions.question_text:
The Account edit button must be overridden in an org where a subset of users still use Salesforce Classic. The org already has a Lightning Component that will do the work necessary for the override, and the client wants to be able to reuse it.
How should a developer implement this?

discussion.content: Its D. You override with a Lightning Component

Selected Answer: D
Lightning Pages are typically used for record pages, app pages, or home pages, not for button overrides.

This approach doesn't directly utilize the existing Lightning Component for Lightning users.

Selected Answer: C
Lightning component—Use the behavior from a Lightning component. Supported only for the Edit, New, New Event, Tab, and View actions. This option isn’t supported for Salesforce Classic.

https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.links_customize_override.htm&type=5
Ans is D
https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/component-library/bundle/lightning:actionOverride/documentation

choices.A: Override the edit button for both Lightning and Classic with a Lightning Component
choices.C: Override the edit button for Lightning with a Lightning Page, and Classic with a Visualforce page that contains the Lightning Component
choices.B: Override the edit button for both Lightning and Classic with a new Visualforce page
choices.D: Override the edit button for Lightning with a Lightning Component, and Classic with a Visualforce page that contains the Lightning Component

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
you can't sync in before triggers as there may be an validation error. its best to do in after trigger and workflow also not even an option as it can't do callouts

Selected Answer: C
I believe the correct answer is C.
Using Process Builder or Flow, you invoke the @InvocableMethod when specific conditions are met.
Within @InvocableMethod, if you want to perform asynchronous processing, you trigger asynchronous processing using classes such as Queueable or Platform Events.
Correct, Id, CreatedDate. and CreatedByld would exist only in after triggers. Workflows can't call methods

questions.question_text:
A developer creates an application event that has triggered an infinite loop.
What may have caused this problem?

discussion.content:
From this url seems to be D:

"Don't Fire an Event in a Renderer
Firing an event in a renderer can cause an infinite rendering loop."

https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.lightning.meta/lightning/events_anti_patterns.htm

Selected Answer: A
The event handler calls a trigger

The renderer of an Aura component should not fire any event. Doing so can cause an infinite rendering loop. Instead, the init handler can be used to run a controller action after construction of the component but before rendering.

choices.C: An event is fired 'ontouchend' and is unhandled
choices.A: The event handler calls a trigger
choices.D: The event is fired from a custom renderer
choices.B: The event has multiple handlers registered in the project

questions.question_text:
An environment has two Apex Triggers: an after-update trigger on Account and an after-update trigger on Contact. The Account after-update trigger fires whenever an Account's address is updated, and it updates every associated Contact with that address. The Contact after-update trigger fires on every edit, and it updates every Campaign Member record related to the Contact with the Contact's state.
Consider the following: A mass update of 200 Account records' addresses, where each Account has 50 Contacts. Each Contact has 1 Campaign Member. This means there are 10,000 Contact records across the Accounts and 10,000 Campaign Member records across the contacts.
What will happen when the mass update occurs?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The mass update will fail since the triggers fire in the same transaction. This will implies 20200 records updated by the DML statement where the limit is 10000

Mass update will fail bcoz If trigger starts working from another trigger, they are executed in same transaction. Please refer the StackExchange: https://salesforce.stackexchange.com/questions/308165/invoking-a-trigger-from-another-trigger-execution-context

Selected Answer: A
Correct ans is A

Selected Answer: A
Both triggers execute in the same context

Selected Answer: A
Each trigger run in it's own context and yet they all share same Transaction context and the governor limit of 10000 DML is for latter, the operation will fail
Mass update will fail with System.LimitException: Too many DML rows: 10001
Ans is B , the first trigger is bellow 10001 threshold
Answer is A as whole transaction will roll-back due to DML error so Account will also not inserted

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, even though both triggers share the same limit, 200 Accounts can be updated because they does not exceed that limit.
